dialogues.text: CLOSE SLOT В— the hand of General Nikolas Pherides  The General's hand spasmodically opens and closes around the of a sword which has been struck into the earth, point foremost as a support. The CAMERA PULLS BACK to reveal his naked forearm and fro this forearm gush gouts of arterial blood. The blood fall into an enamel basin, Over this CLOSE SHOT VOICES can be heard.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Dead on the field, four thousand five hundred seventyВ—two of the enemy В— three thousand of our own men. Burial parties are already at work. We are assigning men from every company to clear the field,

dialogues.speaker: Unknown

dialogues.speaker: Unknown

Four Greek officers stand before the General. are great burly line officers; their uniform tunics open the neck, their caps on the back of their heads and their great sabres trailing along the ground. dialogues.speaker: Unknown

dialogues.speaker: Unknown

dialogues.text: Do you mind if I go with you?

dialogues.speaker: EXT THE ISLE OF THE DEAD

dialogues.speaker: Unknown

dialogues.speaker: Unknown

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (almost whispering) I'll wait here for you.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The General nods, removes his hat and goes into the crypt is lost in the darkness. Oliver tries to peer in after hi The opaque blackness prevents him seeing anything. dialogues.speaker: Unknown

dialogues.text: The General shakes his head..

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: This was the place.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The two men emerge from the tunnel. To the right are limestone cliffs, before them darkness. To the left is pa of a house wall, with a door -- a dark and forbidding doo oak and iron. Now the woman's singing is loud and near. T General stares at the house, looks at the surrounding darkness and then back to the house again.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (bewilderedly) There was no house here.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oliver and the General cross to the house. At the door, t General listens a moment, then lifts his hand and thunder the panels with his knuckles. The sound of the singing br off instantly and they stand waiting in the moonlit silen Suddenly the door opens before them and lamplight makes a frame about them. A man's voice, cheery and welcoming, co from the doorway.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Come in, come in!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: They step through the doorway and the door closes behind them.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It is a lovely room of simple austere proportion, warm wi lamplight, comfortable with chairs and sofas and heated b brazier full of coals. Various antiquities, heads, bits o sculpture, torsos, limbs, bowls, vases amphoras and cylix decorate the room. At one end is a long table on which various shards, artifacts, have been arranged for labor a sorting. On this table are also books and measuring instruments. The various people in the room turn curiously upon the entrance of the soldier and the correspondent. It is Albr who is welcoming, them. He is a Swiss of middle age, a scholarly, gentle man with a humorous smile. Before the brazier, warming his behind under his coattail just as he would have done in Devonshire, is a ruddy-face Englishman, also of middle age. He is formally dressed an has a stiff, official air. This is Mr. Thomas St. Aubyn, British Consul at Adrianople. Seated some little distance from him in a stiff-backed ch is a woman in her early thirties, still possessed of a haggard beauty. There is a curious, restrained stillness about the woman and when she moves it is with a certain careful deliberation. She is working on a hand embroidery frame. After one glance at the newcomers, she pays no fur attention to them. This is Mary Wollsten, secretary to th Consul. She is dressed primly In dark clothing. - - At a small table by himself with a tankard of wine before and an empty wine bottle on the table, is a commercial traveller, Henry Jacks, a Cockney, dressed in a loud, fuz plaid suit, and seeming at this moment to be somewhat the worse for wear and liquor. The General and Oliver look around the room in astonishme Albrecht himself shows some surprise now that he sees the General in the fully lighted room.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (surprised) I took it for granted you gentlemen were refugees as are my other guests.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: This is General Nikolas Pherides, Commander of the Third Army. I'm Oliver Davis. (he hesitates) To be perfectly frank with you, we didn't expect to find anyone living here.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It is my home. (extending his hand) My name is Hugo Albrecht.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oliver shakes hands with Albrecht. The General bows.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I have not been on the island in twenty years. It is changed - changed completely. Where are the graves -- the coffins?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (turning to his guests in polite explanation) This was once a cemetery.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The people in the room exhibit varying degrees of interes

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (smiling) It may seem an odd choice for a home. Yet I like it. (to Oliver and the General) But you must meet my guests.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He half turns to indicate the Consul.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: This is Mr. St. Aubyn, British Consul from Adrianople.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: St. Aubyn bows formally. The General returns his bow with nod, and Oliver goes forward and shakes the Consul's hand

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: --        and Miss St. Aubyn.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Cathy smiles wanly in greeting. Oliver, in American fashi goes from her father to Miss St. Aubyn, takes her hand.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You were singing, weren't you? A beautiful voice, Miss St. Aubyn.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (masking irritation) That was my companion. She sings little peasant songs quite nicely -- a completely untrained voice, of course.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: St. Aubyn continues the introductions, indicating the som faced woman, who sits apart from the others.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: My secretary, Miss Wollsten.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: At this point, Jacks rises unsteadily and lurches towards others. He flashes a card from his pocket.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Jacks -- Henry Jacks. Tinware, best grade and the lowest prices -- (as if quoting a well known slogan) Jacks sells no junk.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The General looks at him, astonished at this strange commercial personality. Oliver, having shaken hands with Wollsten, nods across to Jacks amiably.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Aren't you a little out of your territory?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: If the world won't come to Jacks, Jacks goes to the world.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He walks unsteadily back to his own seat.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mr. Jacks is a philosopher. (to the General) (and Oliver) But, come, sit down with us. We are all anxious to hear of' today's battle.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (to General) A fine fight, sir, but a bit inconvenient for travel. We were under constant shelling all the way down the coast.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The enemy is in retreat. There will be no more fighting here. (to Albrecht) I came here to visit the crypts. My wife was buried here. What happened to the bodies?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: They were gore before I came here.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: But why?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ida, the woman servant, a middleВ—aged Greek woman in pea costume, with a dark sombre face, comes in. She has an amphora of wine and two glasses in her hands. She pours w for Oliver and hands him the glass, then turns to the Gen and begins to pour for him as he and Albrecht talk.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: There was some trouble here В—В—the villagers on the mainland В—-this island was the focal point of their anger. They came here В—В—broke open the tombs and despoiled the graves.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: All the graves?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm afraid so. There were rumors В—В—people were aroused. Some feared restlessness among the dead you know, the old superstitions.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I donut understand.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I can explain, Master Soldier.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She has put down the amphora so that her hands are free. lifts a foreВ—finger to each side of her mouth and grimac between the upright fingers.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (understanding her immediately) Vorvolakas!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hastily Ida crosses herself, at the same time nodding agreement

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (not too unpleasantly) You are an old fool.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (grinning; pleased at this insult from her heroic countryman) You think so? You think such things do not happen? Right now В—В— upstairs there is one who is rosy and bright В—В— full of blood -- and here В—В— (she makes a sidewise inclination of her head toward Mrs. St. Aubyn) В—В—        here is one who is pale and cold as a lily.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You are still a fool.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ida laughs and Albrecht picks up the amphora and starts t pour another glass of wine for the General.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (to Albrecht) You know the Greek legends, you drink the Greek wine, but you are not a Greek.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Albrecht is carrying the wine jug and glasses to a small table near the brazier.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I am, Greek, sir, by affection. Albrecht puts down the jug and the glasses and turns to General.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: But the gods played a little trick on me. I was born in Switzerland.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (pointing to an antique statue) You collect these to sell, abroad?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Albrecht, starting to pour from the wine jug, shakes his head.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (shaking his head) No more. One day I stood in the Royal Museum at Munich and watched the fat burghers and their broodВ—mare wives staring and poking at my beautiful trophies. Now I am content just to live В—В— here in the heart of a vanished world.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (butting in without moving from his place) I wish it'd vanish, I do. I'd give every bloomin' statue in the place for one whiff of fish 'n' chips В—- for one peek at Piccadilly.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Each to his taste.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Jacks gets up, lurching and steadying himself on the tabl

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm going back, first boat to England. I'm going back and hear the sound of Bow Bells. (gets up and starts to the stairs; complaining as he walks) I'm not well. I'm not well. Something's wrong with me В—В—something hurts.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (disdainfully) Odd way to describe plain drunkenness.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Jacks pays no attention to him, but goes on up the stairs the rest watching. The stairs are lit in such a way that upper portion is in complete darkness, shadowed by the landing above.  As Jacks disappears into this darkness, t is a sound of a heavy fall, a muttered curse. They all tu to face the staircase and Oliver and the General get to t feet. Albrecht picks up a lychnos and crosses quickly to stairs, followed by St. Aubyn. As he holds the lamp aloft the General comes to stand beside him. MED. SHOT В— past Albrecht, St. Aubyn and the General at foot of the stairs, to the upper portion of the stairs, n lit by Albrecht's lamp. Jacks lies sprawled across the to step. Bending over him is a girl in Greek native costume, gold coins of her headdress trembling at her ears, as if had been arrested in startled movement. The girl, Thea, slowly lifts her head to face the people below her. As sh does so, the General makes a sudden move forward: a move recognition and astonishment В—В— then restrains himself stand rigidly still. MED. SHOT В— Thea.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (simply) He fell.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: As if words had released them, Albrecht and. St. Aubyn st up the stairs to Jacks.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (a little breathless) That's a strong wine В—В— poor fellow, I should have warned him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: As they reach Jacks, who is mumbling and trying to get to feet, Thea starts down the stairs. It is then that she se the General, who still stands rigid, staring up at her as she were an apparition. She hesitates a moment, a step or above the bottom of the stairs, held there by the General fixed gaze. Behind her, Albrecht and Ida have gotten Jack his feet. The man is muttering incoherently.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: There -- you're all right, now В—В—        we have you В—В—

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (disgustedly) Never mind. It'll get him to his room.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ida and Jacks go on upstairs and Albrecht holds the lante to give them light. The General stares at Thea. CLOSE SHOT В— Oliver. He is staring off in the direction the staircase, his face revealing pleasure in seeing this beautiful Greek girl. ANOTHER ANGLE В— Thea and the General. Thea is looking ba toward Jacks. The General is studying her. Suddenly, she turns toward him to go down the stairs. For a moment she faces him full face. He looks at her in amazement greatly agitated. CLOSE SHOT - The General looking at Thea. His face is strained and he seems to have suffered from a shock. MED. FULL SHOT - The General watching Thea. Albrecht comi down the stairs looks at him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: My dear sir, you look completely exhausted.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The General attempts to pull himself together.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (coming into the scene) He is exhausted.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Why don't you stay here tonight? Get a good sleep. You can return to your command in the morning.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The General is about to shake his head in a negative answ when he suddenly thinks better of it and still looking at Thea, speaks.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Perhaps I had better stay. I am tired.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'll get Ida to make up your bed.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He starts upstairs. Oliver and the General turn back into room. TWO SHOT        В— Cathy and Thea. They arc seated on the CAMERA is set up TO SHOOT PAST their profiles        so t and the General can be seen coming down the room from the stairway in the background.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (to Thea) The young man, Mr. Davis, seems to be some kind of an unofficial observer В—В— a correspondent of some sort В—В—

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: And the soldier -- He looked at me so strangely -- who is he?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Before Cathy can answer Oliver has come close to stand be them. In the background General Pherides has crossed to t brazier where Mr. St. Aubyn stands.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I don't really know where Thea comes from. The ViceВ—Consul at Adrianople brought her to me..

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Her name is Thea?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Theodosia.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Her family name?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Damn me, if I know. She's become so much a member of our household I never think of her by any name but Thea -- she has a last name --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He wrinkles his forehead.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I seem to have forgotten.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The General looks at him suspiciously.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You do not know her last name -- you do not know from where she came?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (looks off at his secretary) Miss Wollsten -В— my secretary, she'd know.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: MED. FULL SHOT - Miss Wollsten. She gets up, places one o the long needles she uses in her embroidery work through collar of her dress and starts toward the stairway. FULL SHOT - The General and St. Aubyn as they watch Miss Wollsten pass. She nods "good night." The General turns b to St. Aubyn.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (with a gesture toward Cathy) Your daughter is ill.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (brushing off the question) She's not too well.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (persistently) What is her illness?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Nothing, really. She's been under a great strain -- the journey -- the battle --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Was she ill before that girl came into your household?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (embarrassed at this interrogation) Why -- no not before Thea came В—В—

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The General looks at him and then at Thea.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Your daughter is weak -- she feels as if the blood had been drained from her -- and all this since that girl came to work in your house.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: St. Aubyn looks at him in annoyance. This volunteered diagnosis offends him. He turns toward the stairs. The General turns with him, taking hold of his arm to stop hi

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: This girl --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (interrupting) This girl -- Thea В—- is not a servant in my household, sir. She is my daughter's companion. Now, sir, if you'll excuse me, I'll go have a look at Mr. Jacks.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I will go with you.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mr. St. Aubyn starts for the stairs and the General stalk after him. The two men reach the foot of the stairs MED. CLOSE SHOT - Oliver with Thea and Cathy. He smiles i friendly fashion at Thea, as he says:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I hope Mr. Jacks gets to bed in one piece.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: M~ father will take care of it. (gushing to impress Oliver) Pappa is wonderful! No matter what happens, he makes me feel perfectly safe. (with flirtatious emphasis) I could never leave him. I should be utterly helpless by myself.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (gravely) You are fortunate in your father.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Thea is an orphan.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (to Thea) That was a lovely song you sang before we came. Sing it again, will you?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Thea smiles, pleased at his request. Before she can reply Cathy breaks in.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (apologetically) I adore hearing Thea sing -- but my poor head's beginning to ache. (exaggeratedly) I'm so sorry.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (courteously) Of course. Tomorrow, perhaps, before I go?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Thea nods and Oliver looks at her, seeing how very beauti how very desirable she is. He smiles and a radiant answer smile comes to her lips. Cathy, watching them, draws thei attention with a sigh. She leans back against the pillows exhaustedly and a little shudder moves her shoulders. The instantly all concern, bends over her.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You have a chill! You must have a glass of wine.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She crosses quickly to the little table and picks up the amphora. She brings it back with her, Oliver and Cathy ar talking. She has to wait, holding the cold pitcher until Cathy turns and holds out her glass. Cathy waits for Oliv to finish speaking before she passes the glass to Thea.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You can imagine the General's disappointment when he found his wife's body gone.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He turns to Thea.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Then we heard you singing --it was so strange and eerie in a place where we had thought there was only the dead.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: As Oliver finishes speaking, Cathy holds out her glass to Thea, who begins to pour wine into it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I was thinking of death when I sang.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (protesting) Thea!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Thea finishes pouring the wine and puts down the amphora. chilled jug has made her hands cold. She rubs them togeth then blows on them. Cathy and Oliver watch her, both smil Cathy shivers.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You're making me feel cold.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Thea is instantly concerned.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Perhaps my scarf --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Thea nods, smiles and willingly goes to get it. FULL SHOT - Thea. The CAMERA PANS WITH her to the foot of stairs. Here she pauses and from a small marble bench tak up a lychnos, sets it alight from another that is burning there and with this lamp in her hand begins to ascend the stairs. MED. SHOT of the stairs. Tall and lovely, with almost measured grace, Thea ascends the stairs to the second flo landing, then comes up onto the landing and pauses, looki down the corridor. She holds up her lamp. LONG SHOT - CAMERA SET UP BEHIND Thea, so that it sees wh she sees before her. In the corridor there are three poin of illumination. One from the skylight; two from windows. These three sources of light cut the blackness of the corridor into almost equal sections; oblongs of blackness alternating with rectangles of grey moonlight. Around The there is a nimbus of weak and~ wavering light, the illumination from her little lamp. The whole corridor is very still, very oppressive. Thea d in her breath almost as if taking courage, and moves towa the first patch of blackness. At its edge she hesitates a steps forward, with a little rush of movement. For a mome she is lost to view, then emerges in the first patch of moonlight. She moves slowly across this. Then again, at t very edge of the second section of darkness, she pauses. There is a little sound in the darkness; some scuffling o papers or blowing curtain. She stops stock still, begins lift her lamp. The lamp flame flickers, and then a sudden soft draft makes the flame lean far from the wick, pulsat puff out. The loss of the light leaves Thea cleft between darkness and moonlight. Again she takes a sharp intake of breath, again moves on and is lost to view, only to emerg again in the second section of light. She moves normally across this patch toward the darkness of a door set into deep embrasure. MED. CLOSE SHOT as Thea emerges from the darkness and tur right, her hand already outstretched for the doorknob. A figure obtrudes itself from the deeper blackness of the d embrasure. A hand reaches out to seize her wrist. She giv half stifled scream of fear and looks up into the face of General as it emerges into the light.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You blew out the light -- to see better in the darkness.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Thea shakes her head, perplexed, still frightened. She lo at the lamp in her hand. The General reaches out his hand point out the lamp. Their hands touch. He draws his hand quickly.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: And your hands are cold В—- cold as dead hands.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Thea is too terrified to speak.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (with menacing softness) You. You know me?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Thea shakes her head, too torrified to speak.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Swear it. By your winding shroud, do you swear it?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Thea shrinks away, still unable to utter a sound. The Gen realizes that his questioning is futile. He releases her wrist, but still holds her fast with his fixed, accusing gaze.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (slowly) Maybe you have no memory for the past В—В— (in a whisper) Vrykolaka!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: With the word, terror takes her. She makes a quick moveme to flee. Just as quickly he seizes her, dragging her to h He has to hold both her hands; then pulls her up against chest. He repeats the word without any special meaning. H face, across which a narrow beam of light falls obliquely grotesque and horrible. The girl struggles and her strugg free one hand. She pushes herself away from him and quick makes the sign of the cross between herself and the Gener at the same time whispering hurriedly.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Christ be with me В—В—

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: For a bare second, there is silence between them and then quite suddenly, he releases her other hand and begins to with laughter. She stands amazed, too wonder-struck even flee, almost gaping at him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (through his laughter) You thought me a Vrykolaka -В—a vampire - -

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He pinches his arm.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Look -- I am alive.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He begins to laugh again.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: And I thought the same of you! (sobering) I am ashamed. A grown man --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The General smiles in ridicule of his own foolishness,

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We of the mountain villages are strange people. There are too many old dreams in our blood, eh?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Thea smiles in agreement.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Then you can understand -- you can forgive me.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Again she smiles. He starts to move away from her. He has gone through the black patch of darkness nearest them and emerged into the moonlight on the other side. She lifts h head and calls to him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: General В—В—

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He turns.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What do they call you? What is your name?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Nikolas Pherides.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He turns and continues down the corridor. CLOSEUP of Thea. A strange look comes over her face. From stare, it is evident that the name strikes some sharp cho in her mind.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It is a bright morning and between the two portals of a ruined temple can be seen the sunlit sea. (See page 98 "Hellas") In the space between the two portals, three people are grouped, Cathy, Thea and Albrecht. Cathy is seated on one the white stones, leaning back against the wall, a rug wrapped about her knees. Albrecht stands behind and a lit in back of her, while Thea stands leaning gracefully agai the opposite portal, half silhouetted against the brightn of the sea. For a moment they remain quiet, then suddenly Thea throws her arms in a gesture of ecstasy and speaks almost as if herself.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The sea! The sea!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Albrecht stares at her, arrested by the words.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What made you say that, Thea?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The moment is broken. Thea looks at him self-consciously, then shakes her head.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I don't know.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: "The sea В—- the sea." Those were the very words of Xenophon and the ten thousand - - do you know about them, Thea?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Smiling, Thea shakes her head.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You don't have to. It's inside of you -- all the glory that was Greece -В— the dancing, the singing and the white marble --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: How clover you are, Mr. Albrecht, to see all that in our simple Thea... She is quite pretty, isn't she?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (disregarding her; pointing to a column) This was the temple of Hades --the God of the Dead. It contained no images -- just empty space and walls of perfect symmetry.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (looking about her) How disappointing! I expected it was something more romantic. A temple to the Goddess of Love, perhaps.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (looking off) The Greeks thought death was beautiful -- an adventure --a journey to another world. (after a little pause) But I have my other guests to think of -- The General will be wanting to go back to his army. If you'll excuse me --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He starts off. The two girls watch him go into the grove. Thea seats herself beside, Cathy. CLOSE TWO SHOT - Thea and Cathy.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Cathy В—- how does it feel to have a father?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What an odd question!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I mean, does one love a father because he is good and kind -В—or just because he is one's father?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (out of her depth) Why, I love my father because - because I do. Of course, he's nice to me.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Cathy leans over toward her.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Thea -- you're hiding something. Why do you suddenly speak of your father? You told me once you had never seen him -- didn't know him --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I do not know him, but I have seen him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What is it -- what are you talking about?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You have forgotten my last name?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Cathy thinks a moment, then smiles.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I have forgotten it, dear.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: My last name is Pherides.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Cathy looks at her in astonishment.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The General is seated on the edge of his cot still in his shirt sleeves. He is pulling on his boots. Oliver has bee washing at the little wash stand and is drying his face w a small towel. Oliver begins to whistle merrily as he thr the towel down. The General looks at him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You are a happy man Oliver. You have but one world to live in В—- the world of today. I have two worlds. I have that old dark world of peasant ignorance and superstition in which I was brought up and a new world which the army gave me В—В— a world of mathematics,  gun ranges,logistics, tactics, strategy.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (grinning) It doesn't seem to bother you much, General.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I will be glad to leave this island. It has too much of that old dark world about it. I will be glad to leave it and that girl В—В—

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Thea?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The General nods.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: There is something evil about her.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh, now В—В— now look here В—В—

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (interrupting) I know all you are going to say В—-I have been saying it to myself, but the thought will not leave my mind. She resembles my wife -В—there is something about her В—В—the way she moves В—В— the way she turns her head.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: But that should make you like her.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The General shakes his head/

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It makes me fear her.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (shrugging) I can't understand that.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It is not necessary to understand. We are leaving and I am thankful.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: CLOSE SHOT - Thea and. Cathy. They are talking earnestly.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Thea, your choice is a very simple one. Either you want to claim him as your father, or you do not.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: But one must love a father.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The General В— you don't even know him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: There is a little silence while Thea looks toward the gro at her feet.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Come, Thea, if you're going to claim him as your father you've got to make up your mind. They'll be leaving any minute.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I don't know. As a child. I longed for a father and now В—- I don't know В—В—

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Thea is still hesitant; still trying to puzzle it out.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Do you like what you've seen, of him'?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Thea shakes her head.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I felt he did not like me.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That should decide it or you --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I will let him go. He is dead to me as he is to all my mother's people. I turn my hand against him.

dialogues.speaker: INT THE GENERAL'S ROOM
dialogues.text: Oliver and the General are ready to depart. Oliver takes last look around the room to see that they have left noth The General stands by the door buckling on his belt.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well, at any rate, I would like to say goodbye to the girl.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We have no time for that.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oliver shrugs.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ready?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The General nods and straightens his coat under his belt. Oliver throws open the door and they start out.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The CAMERA is set up in the doorway of the bedroom TO SHO PAST Oliver and the General as they go out a Albrecht is coming down the stairs.  He is hurrying and is very excit

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Wait, gentlemen! Wait!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: They turn to him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I need your advice В—В— something has happened В—В— Mr.  Jacks В—В—

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Drunk again?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He's dead. I want the General to see him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: If you wish.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Albrecht nods gratefully, turns, and they follow him as h starts up the stairs.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The three men, Albrecht, Oliver and the General come to t second floor and start down to the last door. The CAMERA TRUCKS BEFORE them.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He was going back to hear the sound of Bow bells. He'll never hear them again.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: They stop in front of the door to Jacks' room. Albrecht o it. Through the doorway can be seen a sheeted body on the bed; the face covered. The three men stop in the doorway.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He complained of not feeling well. I thought he was drunk В—В—        he staggered.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That staggering. His dying so quickly.  (to General) In your campaigns, have you never seen men who staggered before they died, who talked incoherently В—В— walked blindly.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I've seen men die drunk В—- and I've seen men die of the plague.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (aghast) Plague? There's no possibility of that, is there?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The rider on the pale horse is Pestilence. He follows the wars.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm not sure that it is the plague.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We will know when the next one sickens. (to Oliver) Until then you and I remain here. I will not bring the plague to my troops.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: In the meantime it would be useless to alarm the others. (nodding) Let them think it was a normal (glancing into Jacks' room) And, perhaps it was В—- perhaps it was.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The oil lamps are lit. Albrecht has assembled his refugee guests at two tables. They are just finishing dinner. Oli and Thea sit at the same table.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (to Oliver) I'm glad you and the General didn't have to leave us. We would feel quite deserted..

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (with a look which divides his compliment between Cathy and Thea) How could we go back to the wars with such pleasant company here..

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (smiling) Thank you.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Thea smiles, pleased. Mr. St. Aubyn looks at his daughter smiling and gay.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You're feeling better, Cathy? (to Albrecht) I must admit your island is peaceful enough. Even I have relaxed.. (smiling) In fact, I feel quite exhausted.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He lifts his hand to his forehead.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (concerned) Perhaps you should rest for a little while, Mr. St. Aubyn.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: St. Aubyn dismisses the suggestion with a gesture.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (to Oliver) Pappa is so strong. Not a bit like me. Even as a child, I was delicate. Then Mamma died, everyone thought I should die, too.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oliver smiles politely but avoids the invitation to flirtation. Instead, he turns to Thea.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Thea, you've hardly said a word all through dinner. (troubledly) I feel something strange in the house В—В— cold.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The General turns to look at Thea, his eyes sombre and questioning.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You're afraid because Mr. Jacks is upstairs.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (shaking her head) The dead are dead.. They can do no harm.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Albrecht moves to get up from the table.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Miss Thea complains of the cold. Let's go to the fire.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The guests rise and the men stand back as Cathy, Thea and Miss Wollsten go out of scene, towards the other end of t large room. Albrecht who has drawn glasses and a wine bot towards him, lifts one of the glasses toward St. Aubyn questioningly.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: St.  Aubyn?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (shaking his head) An excellent wine, no doubt, but it has rather a curious brassy taste in my mouth. No I really quite tired.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: An alert, speculative look comes into Albrecht's face as watches St. Aubyn move out of scene. MED. SHOT, Cathy, Thea and Miss Wollsten have seated themselves around the brazier, Miss Wollsten already at w on her interminable embroidery. St. Aubyn passes them, go to the staircase in b.g. Miss Wollsten looks up and watch him anxiously. Cathy also looks up.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Good night, Pappa.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: St. Aubyn smiles at her, with an effort, and starts slowl the stairs.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ANGLE SHOT of St. Aubyn coming up the stairs. A few steps from the top, he stops; falters and almost loses his bala He clutches at the balustrade to save himself from fallin For a second, he stands there almost doubled over, his fa drawn from a sudden onslaught of pain. Then he straighten himself with an effort and pulls himself slowly up the remaining steps. At the head of the stairs, he goes past camera. CAMERA PANS TO show him start down the murky corridor, staggering as if he were drunk. He hesitates, t turns and lurches to the third door at the left, opens it goes in. MED. CLOSE SHOT. Albrecht, Oliver and the General, at the table, are watching St. Aubyn's o.s. exit. They speak in whispers.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Did you hear what Thea said -- as if she knew what threatens us.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That's impossible. I told them Jacks died of a sudden heart attack, probably brought on by over drinking.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Did your servant got word to Dr. Drossos?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Albrecht picks up the wine bottle and the glasses.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (nodding) Dr. Drossos should be here any hour now.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: WIDER ANGLE. Cathy and Thea are paying no attention to th men across the room, but Miss Wollsten is watching them covertly. As the men start across to the brazier, Albrech carrying the bottle and glasses, she gathers together her embroidery and stands up.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: If you'll forgive me...I've letters to write.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The others call out "good night" to her as she crosses to stairs and begins to ascend. Albrecht and the General go small table, where Albrecht puts down the bottle and glas Oliver joins Cathy and Thea.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (to Oliver) I've just been admiring Thea's headdress. I think I shall have a hat made like it a little round cap with a veil В—В—

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oliver, scarcely hearing her prattle, looks off toward th now empty staircase.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Miss Wollsten comes up the stairs. She hesitates a moment the first door on her left and then walks past it and goe down to the third door. She knocks. There is no answer. S opens the door. The room is dark. She goes in.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The General and Albrecht sit drinking. Albrecht is showin the old soldier a Grecian helmet. The General holds it in hands, studying it carefully and with something close to affection. Cathy and Thea are standing with Oliver at the foot of th stairs.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Good night, Oliver.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sleep well.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The two girls, start up the stairs,Oliver looking after t pityingly.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (over her shoulder) You're not leaving tomorrow..?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I think not.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Thea half turns to look back at Oliver; a long sweeping l Thea and Cathy continue upstairs and Oliver turns back to where the other two men arc seated.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The General and Albrecht are still sitting together. Oliver stands near them.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Until we know, what choice is there? We have to stay.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: But the war, the army В—В— they need you.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Better no general than one carrying the plague.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We still don't know that it's the plague В—В—

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (adamantly) Dr. Drossos will tell us. We will know what to do then.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oliver gives a little shrug of resignation and walks a fe steps into the room, head down, hands in his pockets. Then he turns, grinning ruefully. -

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I wonder if my editor's psychic? Reports from the Greek front are going to be a little vague.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (chuckling) Or even spirit messages from the next world.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oliver's eyes widen and then he smiles quizzically at Albrecht.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (nods thoughtfully) I suppose a war correspondent could get the plague. (cheerfully) Well, I'd better try for some sleep В—- while I'm alive to enjoy it. Good night, gentlemen.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He starts for the stairs. The CAMERA DOLLIES WITH him, th PANS WITH him as he climbs.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oliver comes up onto the landing and starts down the corridor. Suddenly, a shadowy form materializes from the darkness and a voice whispers to him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mr. Davis -В—

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oliver, startled, stops and stares.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Will you help me? Mr. St. Aubyn is ill В—- very ill

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (starting forward) His room is down here, isn't it?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: MED. FULL SHOT. Both girls are in their beds and both see be asleep. CLOSE SHOT В— Cathy. She sleeps soundly. CLOSE SHOT В— Thea. She is wide awake listening to the so of excited footsteps in the hall. Thea looks toward the d INSERT        THE BOTTOM OF THE DOOR FRAME AND THE FLOOR. passes the door. There is darkness then more light goes p MED. CLOSE SHOT В— Thea. She rises to one elbow and waits a moment, watching the closed door. Then she swings her f to the floor and begins to reach for a wrapper which hang the foot of the bed. She puts it on, stands up and starts tiptoeing across the room, CAMERA PANNING WITH her.  CAME HALTS as Thea pauses at the foot of Cathy's bed. She look the motionless figure of the sleeping Cathy. Then, CAMERA PANNING WITH her again, she goes to the door and stands there, listening.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: DOLLY SHOT. Albrecht and the dapper, uniformed figure of Drossos come down the corridor. The CAMERA DOLLIES BEFORE them.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: If he's not dead, he's certainly a sick man.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Albrecht and Dr. Drossos turn at St. Aubyn's door and go

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oliver and the General are standing at the foot of St. Aubyn's bed. Miss Wollsten stands near the head of the be looking down at the motionless figure of the consul. Albr and Dr. Drossos enters Dr. Drossos nods to the General an crosses to the bed.  While the others wait tensely, he fe the man's pulse. He shakes his head and takes hold of the blanket's edge, to pull it up over the dead man's face.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (fighting hysteria) No. No. I won't believe it. He's not dead.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: This is Dr. Drossos, chief medical officer of my division.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I don't care who he is. He doesn't know.        He can't tell В—В—

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (pityingly) I'll make any test you want. Look.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Dr. Drossos plucks a feather from the pillow, a little cu of fluff,and holds it before St. Aubyn's mask-like face. INSERT        THE FEATHER at St. Aubyn's face. It doesn't move.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (stubbornly) He's not dead. I tell you he's not dead.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Dr. Drossos sighs. He turns and picks up a hand mirror fr the chest of drawers behind him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: If there is the finest breath of life it will cloud a mirror.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He takes a handkerchief from his pocket and carefully polishes the mirror to clarity, then holds it before the mouth. He turns the unclouded mirror, so that the others observe it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You see?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (clinging desperately to her delusion) The breath can stop, the heart can stop В—В— it still doesn't mean death. Men have lived --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Dr. Drossos nods with approval. Being entirely devoid of sentiment, his manner is that of a teacher answering the argument of a particularly bright student.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Quite right. In cataleptic trance, a man may live for days with no visible sign of life. The breath suspended,the heartbeat stilled-- (looking down at St. Aubyn) But this man is dead.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Dr. Drossos turns away to replace the mirror on the chest drawers. As he does so, Oliver steps forward and starts t pull the blanket over the dead man's face. Again, Miss Wollsten stops it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What difference does it make? Covered or uncovered, the eyes see no more.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: As he speaks, the General starts toward the door.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: CLOSE SHOT ON closed door of St. Aubyn's room. The door o and the General starts to step into the corridor. He is suddenly motionless, obviously arrested by something he s CAMERA DRAWS ASIDE TO disclose Thea. The girl evidently i frozen in the act of trying to slip away. She starts to p her hand to her throat, but, as she is not wearing the necklace, fumbles nervously with the collar of her robe. Then, still under the General's relentless stare, she goe back to her room. At this moment, Oliver comes out of St. Aubyn's room. He looks down the corridor, then worriedly to the General. Albrecht and Dr. Drossos also come out an the four men start toward the stairs.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Miss Wollsten stands looking down at St. Aubyn, then sudd she takes from her bodice a long embroidery needle  Still gazing intently into his face, she jabs the needle deep i the dead man's arm. There is no reaction in the marble se the corpse's face. Miss Wollsten pulls the blanket over the dead man's face suddenly bursts out weeping, burying her face in her hand

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Morning sunlight pours in through the windows. Cathy sits near the door, crying delicately into a lace handkerchief Thea stands beside her. Thea's expression betrays grief, it is the controlled and dignified grief of the peasant w knows death as intimately as life and is equally at peace with both. Near them is Miss Wollsten, stony-faced and composed. Oliver is seated on the table, swinging his fee The General stands in the open doorway looking toward the sea. Dr. Drossos and Albrecht stand together in the cente the group.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We are faced with a very serious form of plague. Its first symptoms are dizziness, nausea, weakness, inability to focus the eyes or control the limbs. This is followed by acute spasms, sometimes blindness, and finally, in moat cases, death.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (frantically) I don't want to hear any more. You can't keep me here. This horrible island В—В— it has cost me my father В—В— it will kill all of us.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The General turns his head and looks at Cathy without emotion.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (implacably) I will not have the plague carried to my troops. No one leaves here В—not you, not I, not anyone.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oliver goes over to the distraught and weeping Cathy, put his hand on her shoulder sympathetically.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The doctor only wants us to know  the worst, for our own good. Besides, he holds out some hope --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oliver turns to Dr. Drossos, who nods slowly.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: If the wind shifts, if the sirocco blows -- the hot wind from the South -- all danger will be over in twenty-four hours.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (to Drossos gentle mockery) Good winds and bad winds!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Albrecht goes to the table.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (patiently) The disease is transmitted by fleas and their bodies are eighty percent moisture. The hot wind literally burns them away.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Albrecht takes the bronze trident from the figure of Pose and fingers it thoughtfully as he speaks?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The ancient Greeks had just as good an explanation -- that the gods sent the plague to punish mortals for harboring Vrykolaka --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (impatiently) They used to believe that sort of thing in the mountain villages. Some still do --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He glances at the General and then at Thea.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (with serious determination) I do not.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Albrecht, still holding the trident, walks over to the op doorway where the General stands. Miss Wollsten gets to h feet suddenly and faces the men with a look of scorn, alm of hatred.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (to Drossos) If you have nothing more to tell us, will you excuse me В—-

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Dr. Drossos bows and Miss Wollsten crosses the room to th staircase. CLOSE SHOT. At the foot of the staircase Miss Wollsten tu with one of her curious, inimicable glances, then begins climb the stairs. MED. SHOT - on remaining group.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She's right. This is hardly the time to bandy old tales.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I have lived long enough to doubt everything -- which is to say, I believe everything, a little.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Albrecht goes to the table and replaces the trident.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You're just talking nonsense.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Let us put it to the test. Protect yourself with every scientific precaution you can think of. I'll go out on the cliff and build a votive fire to Hermes -- not that I believe in him any more than I do in Science.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Dr. Drossos gives a little snort of disdain.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (smiles) We will see who is the first to die.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (smiling wryly) Very well. I'll wager a dinner.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It is a moonlit night and the cypress trees cast deep sha across the marble flooring of the terrace. From somewhere on the island, possibly played by one of t servants, comes the sound of a Greek bagpipe blatting its shrill and mournful music into the still air. The CAMERA is set up TO TAKE IN the balcony from one end. Thea, Oliver and Cathy are together. Cathy is stretched o on a settee with a robe over her knees. Oliver and Thea s together near one of the pillars.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (commiseratingly) I know it must be hard. But you have relatives in London --you've got a whole world of living, ahead of you --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (on the verge of the tears which are so easy for her) No one can take my father's place.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She gropes around as if looking for something.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: My handkerchief -В— I think I must have lost it В—- perhaps when we were in the grove. (with a preemptory note) Thea!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Thea bestirs herself out of whatever reverie has held her

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'll find it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She starts off toward the right. Oliver looks at her.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You can't go down there alone - -

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He takes a few quick, long strides and catches up with he Cathy is left completely alone. She looks off at the othe two and her customary expression of weak helplessness qui changes to one of anger. She is so intent that she does n notice Miss Wollsten rise from a chair in the b  g., walk through the deep shadows cast by the cypress trees and co noiselessly to stand beside her. Miss Wollsten has to spe to gain her attention.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Cathy --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Cathy looks around at her inquiringly, somewhat startled.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I wish I didn't have such bitter knowledge of you, Cathy.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Whet do you mean?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: They were talking about the Vrykolakas this morning. Cathy, that's what you are В—В— a weak, pale, half-dead thing that drains all the life and joy from those who want to live.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (haughtily; in an attempt to put Miss Wollsten in her place) Miss Wollsten!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You and your mysterious illness. A new attack everytime you are crossed В— everytime you can't get your own way.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Cathy tries to interrupt, but Miss Wollsten goes on ruthlessly.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Your father knew it too. But he was never sure how much was pretense.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (flaring up) How do you know what my father thought - -

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (disregarding her) Your father loved me.  He wanted to marry me. But he was afraid of hurting the gentle, delicate Cathy. You spoiled his life В—В—you've ruined mine В—В—

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You were father's secretary -В— I never thought - -

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Didn't you? But now -- what are you thinking now?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She points over the balustrade toward the cypress grove below.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What would I be thinking?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mr. Davis seems a good prospect В—В—young handsome, sympathetic -- ready to listen to you and feel sorry for you - -

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What if he is?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (disregarding her) ) But Thea -- She stands in your way. I know you. I know your little hints В—В— the way you can turn the truth into a lie --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Why, I'm fond of Thea.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You're planing something, Cathy.. But I won't let you В—- I'll warn them against you.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You will not say one single word.  I know your secret.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That your father and I В—В—

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No. I mean your other secret -В—        the one you kept bidden even from my father. That old doctor in London -- he told me.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She faces her triumphantly.        Miss Wollsten shrinks away. Cathy stands looking after her smiling, then turns walks to the edge of the ruins and looks down into the gr

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Only trickles of moonlight come through the pendulous branches and thick boles of these dark trees. The CAMERA TRACKS TO a space between two of the largest trees, a spa which seems filled only with shadow and moonlight, but as MOVES IN CLOSER, Oliver and Thea are disclosed, embracing They break apart. She starts to turn from him but he take her hand and turns her so that she faces him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Thea.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She allows him to draw her back. CLOSE SHOT В— over Oliver's shoulder at Thea's face. He c his hand around her chin so that she looks up at him. Her eyes are wet with tears.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You're crying. Why?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (simply) I don't know. Everything's so mixed up --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (smiling) Everything's so simple. I like you.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Thea smiles at him affectionately, but then her face clou again and she looks away from him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What's bothering you, Thea? Is it the General?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sometimes when he looks at me in that strange way, I'm afraid of him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Don't let it trouble you. He's an old man and these last few days have been a terrible strain on him. He won't harm you.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She makes a pathetic attempt at a smile. He puts his arms around her protectively and they kiss. Slowly they break their embrace and together they start up the path.

dialogues.speaker: ANOTHER ASPECT OF THE GROVE
dialogues.text: This is at a point where a narrow flight of marble stairs come clown from above         The CAMERA is on the stairs the path.        Oliver and Thea walk in silence, their h clasped.        They come slowly up the path. ANOTHER ANGLE - MED. CLOSE SHOT - Thea and Oliver suddenl look up.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: General Pherides stands there, erect and silent, looking with an expression which is hard to fathom. THREE SHOT. Nervous and embarrassed, Thea disengages her from Oliver's.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You gave us quite a start -- standing there.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The General is silent. Thea moves rapidly toward the stai carefully avoiding physical contact with the General as s goes past him. He does not turn to look at her, but as Ol moves to follow her, the General puts a restraining hand his arm. Then, without a word, he steps down onto the pat and starts along it toward the shore. Oliver looks at him puzzlement, shrugs and then follows him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The two men walk silently through the grove. At the edge the grove on the shoreward side of the island the General Oliver come out from beneath the trees and emerge onto th beach below the figure of Cerberus. The General seats him on a block of stone, looking out toward the sea. Oliver stands near him. The General points out across the water. LONG SHOT - MATTE. The General in the f.g. points to the fires burning on the hills of the opposite shore.,

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Tomorrow they move on to engage the enemy В—В— to beat him back across the Bosphorus.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: CLOSE SHOT - the General has his sabre between his knees is resting his two hands upon it; a melancholy and mournf figure. His eyes are fixed on the distant camp fires. (Note: See famous World-Wide photograph of King Ferdinand Bulgaria, taken after the defeat of the Bulgarian armies

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's hard going, General. You wanted to lead them. Here you are quarantined just because you wanted to pray at your wife's side В—В— and even her body is gone.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The General looks over.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (musing) Thea is so like her В—В— in every feature В—В—

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (rather pleased) If she looked like Thea, she must have been beautiful.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The General takes a deep breath and sighs, remembering ot days.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She was beautiful. There was blood between her family and my kin. But that did not stop me from taking her when I saw her beauty, nor did it stop her from loving me.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: How did she die?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I don' t know. When I was gone the people from her village came to my home seeking vengeance. They bore her away with them. Months later she came back В—В—pale -- sick -- she died --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: There is a long silence. Oliver stirs restlessly.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Is this what you wanted to speak to me about?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: In a way -- this girl, Thea. You must stay away from her.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I had a notion you had become selfВ—appointed chaperone lately В— why?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You are my friend.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: And I'm your friend В—В— but that doesn't explain why you are always trying to come between Thea and me?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: If I told you В—В— you wouldn't believe me -- but this much I can tell you В—В— the girl is dangerous to you. Take a friend's advice -- an old man' s advice -- leave her alone -В—

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (turning away; indignant) That's ridiculous -- Thea's lovely, gentle В—-

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (earnestly) Listen to what I say --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: When you make sense I'll listen.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He starts off, up the path through the grove, the General follows him.

dialogues.speaker: EXT THE GROVE
dialogues.text: Oliver, followed by the General, passes through the grove

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Cathy still sits in the moonlight. Oliver and the General come into the ruins.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Where's Thea?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I think she went to bed В—В— I saw her going toward the house

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oliver makes a vague gesture of disappointment and sits d beside Cathy. While Cathy was speaking, the General had turned to look into the grove. He still stands looking down among the tr

dialogues.speaker: EXT THE GROVE
dialogues.text: LONG SHOT В— of Thea passing between the trees, looking f Oliver.

dialogues.speaker: EXT THE RUINS
dialogues.text: MED. CLOSE SHOT - The General. Oliver and Cathy can be se behind him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (in a low voice) Let the doctor guard us against the plague В—- I shall stand guard against the other things -- the things we cannot understand.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: MED. FULL SHOT, favoring Oliver and. Cathy. They both loo in surprise at the General. He looks at them and then sta off into the darkness toward the house. Cathy watches him

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: MONTAGE OF TIDES - tide running in and out -- day and nig over the sound of Grecian reed pipes, and a voice singing "The Lament of Konos,' the lament that describes how life comes in and goes out with the tides of the sea.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A Greek brazier on a tripod stands before the portal faci the sea. A fire burns in the brazier and Albrecht stands beside it with a handful of twigs which he is about to pu the fire. Dr. Drosssos stands watching him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (turning to him) I suppose you want to hear my prayer to Hermes.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I just came to see if your prayer would entertain me as much as my medicine seems to amuse you.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Albrecht turns his hand and lets the remaining twigs fall onto the fire. It burns up with a bright flame, then a th column of black smoke ascends. He lifts his hands upward the Grecian attitude of prayer.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (teasingly) You're too late, my friend. I have already made my prayers. And how about your scientific efforts?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Dr. Drossos steps forward, bends to pick up some twigs wh are beside the brazier and puts them on the fire.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (dryly) Also too late. I owe you a dinner.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: AS the meaning of this sinks in, Albrecht's bantering man disappears.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (concerned) ) You feel the symptoms?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: My friend -- what can one say --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You can have your servants prepare a dinner. That is the way I'll meet my old- familiar enemy -- Death --I have fought him before. I've won often. Now he wins. Let him come for me at my own banquet.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: FULL SHOT. The little rays of oil lamps which illuminated room during the dinner have been replaced by a great cent lamp, also oil-burning. The long table is in a pool of brilliance; tongues of light from the manifold wicks of t lamp flicker into the outer dimness of the room. As the dinner is almost over, there remain on the table only bow of fruit and dates, wine glasses and the many wine jugs a bottles, some of them empty. At one end of the table sit Drossos, as host, Miss Wollsten, Albrecht and the General the opposite end, as if drawn apart by their mutual youth are Cathy, Thea and Oliver. On the stairs sits the man servant of Albrecht and his bagpipe under his arm. Out of this hairy apparatus he is coaxing folk melodies o his native hills. The woman servant, dressed in gay natio costume, waits on the table. MED. SHOT of Dr. Drossos and group at one end of the tabl Dr. Drossos refills Miss Wollsten's glass and carries the bottle to his own glass with an unsteady hand.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (thickly) When I was a young man, I prescribed moderation in all things. Especially wine.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Dr. Drossos fills his glass to the brim and then continue pouring, so that the bright liquid spills over onto the table. Miss Wollsten laughs softly and a little drunkenly Albrecht takes the bottle out of the doctor's hand, setti it upright again. The General smiles and picks up his win glass.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: When I was young a man was measured by the skins of wine he could empty.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Albrecht looks toward the other end of the table and lift his glass. NED. CLOSE SHOT of Cathy, Thea and Oliver. They are sitti with their heads close together, in intimate conversation Cathy and Oliver are smiling gaily. Thea smiles, too, but rather puzzledly as if the conversation eluded her. Olive speaking in a very low tone, almost whispering. Plainly, wine has had an effect

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (mockly melodramatic) And then - - the Vrykolaka will get you, if you don't watch out...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Cathy, more animated than we have ever seen her between t wine and her growing interest in Oliver, starts to laugh.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh, no -В— it's too delicious! You're making it up!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: On my word! That's what they believe.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (smiling but distressed) Please.. You shouldn't laugh --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (teasing her) You see? Thea believes it, too!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Cathy turns to Thea. Where Oliver's teasing is good-tempe her mocking laughter has an edge of malice to it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Tell me about them, Thea. They have great wings end long teeth --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (embellishing) Sharp, shiny teeth -- and they creep up to your bed --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Closer and closer В—- until they bite into your throat!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: As she says it, Cathy's fingers dart out and touch Thea's throat. Thea gives a little muffled cry and throws hersel back from Cathy. Cathy and Oliver both burst out laughing leaning close together, sharing their childish joke.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh, my poor simple Thea! (to Oliver) Did you ever see anything so ludicrous?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Thea, frightened by the conversation and unhappy because Oliver and Cathy have been making fun of her, starts to g up from the table. MED. SHOT of table, including both groups, with Oliver, C and Thea in the background. As Thea stands up, Dr. Drosso leans forward, peering down the table towards her.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Thea! Come here!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The others turn to look at the girl as she obeys the summ

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Look at her. Warm, beautiful - alive. Drink with me, Thea -В— Drink to my old enemy, who wins at last --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: As Thea comes to stand beside him, Dr. Drossos picks up Albrecht's wine glass and hands it to her. Thea obedientl drinks. In silence they watch her drain the glass, her he going back slowly. It is a beautiful, a pagan gesture.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (almost to himself) There is only one place where the women bewitch one with their beauty.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: CLOSE SHOT of Thea as she starts singing. It's a primitiv sensuous song and Thea's whole body seems to respond.. MED. CLOSE SHOT of Oliver and Cathy, watching Thea. It is obvious that Oliver is bewitched; his eyes follow every m the girl makes. Cathy steals a glance at him. ANOTHER ANGLE as Thea sings; she moves toward Oliver in a series of slow steps. As she comes closer to him, she sta to smile, a slow dreamlike smile that seems to well up fr some deep inner joy. Oliver leans forward, drawn by the g until as she comes within reach he puts out his hand to t her arm. Her smile quivers into a little laugh, at once childish and enticing. She eludes him. At this moment, he song ends. While the        others applaud, she crosses t door. There, she stops abruptly. CLOSEUP of Thea, looking across the room at Oliver. Her f flushed and alive, is a frank invitation, almost innocent its candid admission of desire. Then she slowly turns her head away. CLOSE SHOT of Oliver as Thea slips out the door in the b. He gets to his feet. Cathy puts out her hand to hold him but he doesn't even see it. As Oliver walks past the tabl unsteadily, the General gets to his feet and blocks his w Oliver pushes him aside impatiently.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Everything's dead in here, dead and empty. (gesturing toward the door) Out there; the night is alive.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He continues across and goes out through the door.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (starting for the door; harshly) Someone should go with him. He's has had too much to drink.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Suddenly Miss Wollsten laughs. Cathy whirls around to sta at her angrily. Miss Wollsten returns the stare.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I think Thea is steady enough for both. She has not had too much to drink.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The General looks at her with hatred and crosses back to chair and sits down. Miss Wollsten, with a smile, turns a goes upstairs.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (almost incoherently) Don't go. You are leaving me, you are all leaving me --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Albrecht, instantly concerned, gets up and bonds over the dying man.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm here. The General is here. You are not alone.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (with a last spurt of strength) I must meet him with laughter - with songs and laughter -- to show him I am not afraid --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: With the last words, Dr. Drossos catches up his wine glas but, before he can lift it to his lips he begins to slump his chair. The echo of his final challenge dies. The Gene steps quickly to his side.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He is dying.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Dr. Drossos doubles up in his chair and falls limply forw across the table. His hand relaxes and the wine glass fal the wine spilling out with the doctor's life.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (slowly) When she stood beside him, I knew. I could feel death in the room.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: MED. SHOT В— Cathy, alone, paces the little terrace outsi the house. It is evident that she is disturbed and agitat by something. After a moment, the sound of Thea's voice, singing, comes into the still morning air. Cathy stops, listening. CLOSER SHOT of Cathy, her face hardening with angry jealo as she listens to Thea's clear, sweet song. Oliver comes the ruins. Cathy turns as Oliver comes toward her, smilin he looks off in the direction of the singing.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (emotionally) Oliver --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oliver's smile fades into concern as he comes up to take Cathy's hand in quick sympathy.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What is it, Cathy? What's the matter?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: MED. CLOSE SHOT of Cathy and Oliver. The singing continue over this entire scene, sometimes louder, sometimes faint as if Thea were strolling about the island. Cathy's expression is distraught and she clings to Oliver hand.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: My father -- I'm alone, Oliver, completely alone!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (tenderly) Poor Cathy --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (with rising hysteria) Last night Dr. Drossos -- today you or I -- oh, no, Oliver, it can't be you, I couldn't stand it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Cathy, clutching Oliver's hand tightly, leans toward him yearningly. Oliver, beginning to find her emotionalism awkward and a little distasteful, is deliberately matter- fact now.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: There's no reason to decide any of us are going to die.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: If only we could get away - - you and I. The others are strangers, they mean nothing to me

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Struck by this callousness, Oliver's face loses the last trace of sympathy for Cathy.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (feverishly) We have to get away, we have to live. I have no one in the world -- you must stay with me, care for meВ—

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
