dialogues.text: Making an effort to control his instinctive aversion to h closeness, Oliver takes hold of her arms and pulls them a at the same time stepping back from her. He smiles at her trying to return their relationship to a normal footing.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We'll talk later, when you're yourself again.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Cathy still stands motionless and Oliver walks away in th direction of Thea's singing, which now comes over the sce clearly. CAMERA REMAINS on Cathy, as she watches him go. face contorts and she starts weeping with rage and frustration. Abruptly, she turns and starts off.

dialogues.speaker: EXT THE LANDING OUTSIDE THE TUNNEL
dialogues.text: The General stands here, leaning on his sabre, looking to the mainland from which comes the sound of cannonading. Behind him is a camp chair.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: In the distance small puffs of smoke can be seen and the sound of canon fire comes from afar.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The General looks up at a little flag on a pole which has been erected nearby. It blows south, rippling and undulat in the brisk north wind. He turns to look back at the oth shore. Cathy comes out of the tunnel. The General turns t her.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (looking at the flag) The wind has not changed.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He shakes his head. Cathy sinks down in the camp chair. face still drawn from her emotional upset looks frighteni exhausted.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (compassionately) Poor child. These must be horrible days for you.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm so ill, I'm so exhausted -- I almost don't care.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The General looks at her with heightened attention.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You look so pale this morning, as if all your blood were drained away.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Cathy looks at him, her ego gratefully absorbing this attention and sympathy. The General takes a few steps bac and forth, then stops before her.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Has that girl -- has Thea ever told you where she comes from?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (not liking the change of subject) Some village in the mountains -- Alethera, I think.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The General stands very still.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Has she spoken to you of her father and her mother?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (indifferently) She has never mentioned her family.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: How old is she?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The General waits tensely for the answer, which means so to him. Cathy, now definitely bored by the trend of the conversation, replies cattily:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (indifferently) I don't know --- fairly young.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The General stands silent. Cathy gets up languidly and st for the tunnel.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The sun is so strong here.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The General watches her depart, then walks to the edge of landing and starts down towards the beach.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: LONG SHOT - HIGH CAMERA SETUP. The sunlight drifts in lon beams between the trees. At the end of one of these rays light, Thea is seated on a block of marble. In her lap ar some myrtle leaves and she is happily occupied in weaving them into a crown. MED. CLOSE SHOT - Thea. Suddenly a tall shadow falls over her. She looks up. ANOTHER ANGLE. The General stands before Thea. She looks without a smile of greeting.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You have deceived me long enough. Now I have found out. You are from Alethera -- from where I took you and from where you came to die - - to die without dying - -

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Thea rises and faces him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Why are you making up these things - - why are you wishing evil on me? (as if answering her own question) You know who I am, don't you?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (slowly) I wish I didn't know.        I wish I had never found you again.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I knew you hated me and my people -- but I didn't know your hatred was so bitter --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The General's expression softens. He shakes his head sadl

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It isn't hatred. I couldn't hate you.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Thea looks at him wonderingly, struck by the change in hi tone.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (somberly) I failed you twenty years ago. Now, I've come to do what must be done.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Thea's face lights up. She says, almost hopefully:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: To take me with you?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The General draws back from her in horror, believing as h does that she is a Vrykolaka. With his left hand he begin reach inside his tunic.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (in a hoarse whisper) No - - no -- to do what I should have done.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: At this moment, a call comes from above.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Thea --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The General looks off towards the voice.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Thea --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (calling) I'm here..

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The General lets go her arm.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (in a low voice) I watched you -- you've bewitched him. But he is my friend. You'll not do to him what you have done to the young English girl.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Thea turns and runs. The General stands looking after her

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oliver comes leisurely down the path to the three or four steps which brings it to the floor of the grove. He stops suddenly as Thea runs in very agitated. She runs up to hi and he takes her in his arms.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Thea, what's wrong?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The General threatened me.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (grinning) Oh, that Vrykolaka business. You mustn't be too angry with him, Thea. He's an old man and now with all this trouble В—В— the disappointment in not being able to lead his own army to victory -- cooped up here waiting for death - naturally his mind goes back to the things he believed when he was an ignorant lad in some mountain village.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He keeps asking for the name of my father and mother.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well, tell, him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I can't.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Why in the world can't you?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He hates all my race.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I knew that feuds still went on, but I didn't think people like you and the General would be involved.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It is more than a feud between two families. He stole my mother away from her people.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oliver looks at her, holding her out at arm's length.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Thea, what is this? What are you trying to tell me? "He stole your mother" В—-

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (nodding) It is for that he hates me.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oliver shakes his head.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (earnestly) I don't think so, Thea. He has spoken of your mother. I don't believe he knows you are his daughter.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Then why does he persecute me? My family told me what kind of man he is, how he stole my mother and then abandoned her --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oliver takes her hand.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (gently) They didn't tell you the whole truth. Why do you think your mother went back to him after you were born?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Thea looks at him, uncertain, unconvinced.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Because she loved him. (pauses) I know him, Thea. Believe me, he is not a cruel man.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (slowly) For a moment, when he looked at me so sadly, I felt that I had wronged him. But then --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She shudders, remembering her last sight of the General.'

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Let me tell him. When he knows you are his child, he'll forget these insane notions -В—

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (alarmed) No -- you musn't. He thinks I've bewitched you. He won't believe it В—- he'll hate me even more! My only chance is to stay away from him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oliver puts his arm around her in a protective gesture.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Perhaps you are right. He's not himself now. We'll wait В—В— and in the meantime, don't be afraid I'll take care of you..

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Thea gives him a faint, grateful smile and rests her head against his shoulder trustingly.

dialogues.speaker: THE NARROW LEDGE IN FRONT OF THE CRYPTS
dialogues.text: The General turns onto the ledge and begins walking. From crypt comes the sound of someone moving about. He stops.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A crude wooden coffin stands on two trestles in the cente the crypt. Beside it stands Miss Wollsten. Suddenly the b of the General blocking the doorway shuts off the light falling into the crypt. Miss Wollsten looks up startled. TWO SHOT - The General and Miss Wollsten.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Woman, what are you doing here?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (rising to her feet and attempting to look more normal and a little strange and guilty) I wanted to be sure of something, General -- something that has always preyed on my mind. I have a horror of being buried alive and awakening to find myself shut in В—- entombed В—В— imprisoned..

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (pointing to the coffin) He sleeps quietly. He died with a wine glass in his hand -- he died laughing -- a brave man, Drossos, like his father before him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Because he was a brave man - because I liked him -- I came here to be sure.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He's dead enough. God rest his soul.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He starts to turn away.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: General -В—

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He turns back to her.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm a woman -- a lonely woman. I have few friends.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (impatiently) Yes?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I have not had a happy life --but that one thing - - that terror which brings me awake out of deep sleep В—- I want to avoid it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I don't understand you.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I don't want to be buried alive. If I die I want to be sure В—- quite sure.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: If you should fall sick we'll be careful. You need not worry.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No, I want more than that. I beg you General, make sure --drive a knife through my heart -- anything.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (looking at her in sudden horror) You ask that of me? You're afraid to live in your coffin. You know what that means?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (nods) That's superstition. That's something out of old tales -- about the dead who live В—- I'm talking of something else --cataleptic attacks -- apparent death that is not real.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Never fear -- when you are dead you will remain dead. I will see to it that you do not walk about again. I promise you that. There is another one here who can not die. I will watch you both. Never fear.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He turns and walks away from her. Miss Wollsten looks aft him with a puzzled expression. She makes a half move as i stop him for explanation then thinks better of it and let him go.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Albrecht sits at the long table where he sorts his artifa Oliver sits on the table facing him. THE CAMERA PANS FROM the scientist and Oliver to the woma servant who is setting the table and the man servant who pouring charcoal into the brazier. As the charcoal covers live coals that corner of the room grows dim and the CAME PANS TO the foot of the stairs.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Thea stands in front of the mirror brushing her long hair Suddenly, there is a small movement in the glass alongsid her reflection. She stops brushing, poised in midair, pee into the glass, then whirls to look at the window.

dialogues.speaker: THE WINDOW
dialogues.text: A face hardly discernible and unrecognizable is disappear from the glass. CLOSE SHOT - Thea. She looks in puzzlement at the window, then with a little shrug, she lays down her brush and beg to pile up her hair and put on her head-dress. She finish bends swiftly to put out the oil light and goes out the d The room is plunged into darkness, except for the lighted doorway of Miss Wollsten's room.

dialogues.speaker: INT. THE CORRIDOR NIGHT
dialogues.text: DOLLY SHOT The CAMERA MOVES BEFORE Thea as she comes down dark hallway. The top button of her dress needs fastening she is concentrating on it as she walks. Behind her a vag form seems to be emerging from the darkness. At the stair landing she pauses.

dialogues.speaker: THE TOP OF THE STAIRS
dialogues.text: FULL CLOSE SHOT - Thea - as she pauses to finish adjustin the button. Behind her, the half-seen dimness of the figu that has followed her down the hall emerges fully in the person of the General. Just as he comes into clear perception, Thea finishes fastening the button of her dro and starts down the stairs, quite oblivious of his threatening proximity. He stops at the top of the stairs.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The CAMERA IS SET UP IN a corner with a wide angle lens taking in both the door to the hall and the door to Miss Wollsten's room. The room is in darkness, but Miss Wollst room glows with a dim light. Miss Wollsten comes into the doorway of her room. In her hand is one of the little lychnoses. She hears a knock at the hall doorway. She hesitates a second, then puts out the lamp, plunging the in darkness. At this instant, the door from the hail open admitting light as well as the General. The General strik match and sets flame to the oil lamp which Thea left in t room. When the room is illuminated, Miss Wollsten has disappeared and only the black emptiness of her doorway c be seen. The General holds up the lamp and looks around. walks into the room and CAMERA PANS WITH him as he crosse the window.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: General -В—

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The General turns back towards the hall door, startled. ANOTHER ANGLE - including both the General and Cathy, who stand in the open doorway to the hall.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What are you doing?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I was looking for you.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The General walks over to her.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I have been troubled about you. I want you to know that my room is just downstairs -- (nodding toward hail) You have only to cry out if you are ill В—В— or frightened.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (pleased) How kind you are. It is so comforting to know that someone cares.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: As she speaks, Cathy goes into the room and sits on the e of her bed.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (kindly) You no longer have your father В—- (smiles almost affectionately) And I have no children.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The General turns to leave the room, then looks back towa the other bed.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Miss Wollsten shares the room with you?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No, that's Thea's bed. Miss Wollsten's bed is in there.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Cathy gestures toward the darkened doorway of Miss Wollst room. The General looks for a second longer at Thea's bed then nods as he starts out.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (smiling) I'll see you at dinner.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: As the General closes the door behind him, Cathy gets up crosses to the dressingВ—table. From behind her, out of the darkness of her own room, com Miss Wollsten.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I've always known what an evil mind lay behind that pretty weak face of yours В—В— but this, Cathy -- even I would never have believed it is of you.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (genuinely bewildered) Would you care to explain what you're talking about?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You've been playing on the superstitions of that poor old man В— В— working at him В— В— turning him against Thea.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (angrily) Really, this is idiotic!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You'd do anything to get Oliver away from Thea. But I'm going to stop you. I'm going to tell Mr. Davis exactly what you are.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Cathy's bewilderment has this time given way to rage, as ancient antagonism between the two women flares up again.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: And what makes you think he'll believe you, when I tell him what you are - - what part you played in my father's life --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Miss Wollsten shrinks back from her, appalled at the interpretation Cathy's tone gives to her love for St. Aub

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: When I tell him that you're unfit to live a normal life with normal people В—- a cataleptic!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (stricken) You wouldn't tell that В—В—

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Wouldn't I?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Now, Miss Wollsten's calm leaves her. She almost shrieks the girl.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Then tell them! You're despicable, a monster of vanity with heart for no one but yourself. Tell them everything -- but I will tell them too В—- and you'll lose, Cathy -- you understand -- you'll lose!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She turns from Cathy, picks up the lamp and goes back to own room. Cathy looks after her, her expression of rage fading to an irritated frown. Then, with a shrug, she pic up the lychnos and walks out of the room to the hall.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The bed is turned down and a white cotton nightgown hangs over the footboard. Miss Wollsten picks up a shawl and adjusts it with a frenzied movement about her shoulders. starts to pick up the lamp, then suddenly stops; her face contorts, her lips writhe in strangulated agony and very slowly her knees buckle. She goes to her knees, to all fo and then slides from this position to the floor.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oliver, Thea, the General and Albrecht an already seated the table  Albrecht has a soup tureen before his and is ladling out bowls of soup which the woman servant takes t the various places. Cathy, coming across the room from th staircase, goes to her place.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It has been brisk and warm today. Take comfort  We always have these perfect days before the sirocco blows.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Albrecht starts to ladle out another portion, looks towar the one empty seat and asks:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Where is Miss Wollsten?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She's in her room.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'll get her        --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Thea gets up and moves quickly across to the stairway.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: If Mr. Albrecht is right, we'll all be free in a few days. (to Cathy) I suppose you'll be going on to Athens?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (the usual) I don't know now without my father.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You are right. You shouldn't be traveling alone. (to Oliver) Why don't you make the trip with her?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Cathy turns to Oliver, waiting hopefully for his answer.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (politely disinterested) I'd like to, very much -- but it depends on what dispatches are waiting for me on the mainland.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (to Oliver) In case you do so, would you --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Albrecht's words are cut by terrible shriek from the uppe floor. For a split second, they are sit motionless and th they jump up and rush, to the staircase.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: MED. SHOT on head of stairway as the group come up the stairs. The men, in the lead, cross towards the girls' ro and Cathy hurries after them.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: MED. CLOSE SHOT of Thea bending over the body of Miss Wollsten. Over the scene come the sound of a door opening, quick footsteps and ad lib voices. As Thea raises her head, the CAMERA DRAWS BACK to show the General in the doorway of t room, with Oliver, Albrecht and Cathy behind him. As the General stares into the room, Thea's hand goes up to her necklace. She rises quickly as the General comes forward steps aside. The General drops to one knee beside Miss Wollsten's body. Oliver goes over to Thea and Albrecht comes to stand besi the General.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She is dead.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Cathy, still standing in the doorway, gives a little gasp draws back into her own room. CLOSE SHOT. The General opens the high neck of Miss Wollsten's dress and examines the throat and upper bosom.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: There are no marks.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He looks off toward Thea. MED. SHOT. As Thea shrinks away from the General's look, Oliver puts a protective arm around her and leads her int the other room.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Help me put her on the bed.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The two men lift Miss Wollsten's body from the floor and carry it to the bed.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I want to make those tests that Dr. Drossos made. (looking down at the corpse) I promised her.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He looks around the room, then goes to the dresser and pi up a hand-mirror.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: FULL SHOT - SHOOTING THROUGH the open doorway into Miss Wollsten's room. In immediate foreground Cathy and Thea s on the bed, their backs to the CAMERA. Thea has her arm around Cathy. Leaning on one side of the doorway, so as n to obstruct the view, is Oliver. The General and Albrecht can be seen bending over Miss Wollsten's bed, but we cannot see what they are doing.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Her heart is stopped -- there is no breath.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Nothing. (after a pause) There is a way to make sure -В—

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oliver moves into Miss Wollsten's room, at the same time saying sharply:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No. We can do without that.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: MED. SHOT - the three men.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Another sad task. We'll bury her tomorrow. (gesturing to door) I think we'd better lock the door for tonight. It will make them less uncomfortable.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (positively) No. (looking toward the door) She shall not be left here.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Maybe you're right. Help me get something to carry her downstairs.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The figures of the three men go past the CAMERA. Their footsteps can be heard as they leave the room; the sound the door closing as they shut it behind them. The CAMERA which has remained focused on Miss Wollsten's begins to slowly MOVE IN to an extreme CLOSEUP. Here it h a moment and as it HOLDS there is a sudden twitch of musc in the woman's cheek. As the sound of the men's feet scuffling as they bring in heavy burden is heard, the CAMERA begins to PULL BACK in order to reveal the General, Albrecht and Oliver carrying a heavy packing box of the sort that the archaeologist us to ship statues and pieces of heavy stone carving. They put the box on the floor, line it with a blanket and then lift Miss Wollsten and place her in the box. While t General and Oliver get the lid from the hall, Albrecht notices the white cotton nightgown on the foot of the bed picks it up. They put the lid on the box and start to lif it.

dialogues.speaker: THE CYPRESS GROVE
dialogues.text: LONG SHOT. Thea is seated and she watches Oliver, Albrech the General and the man servant as they carry the heavy b down the path from the house. Behind the men and their bu walk Cathy, Thea and the woman servant.

dialogues.speaker: THE LEDGE IN FRONT OF THE CRYPTS
dialogues.text: The little procession comes up onto the ledge and starts walking along it to the nearest crypt, the one next to th occupied by the remains of Dr. Drossos.

dialogues.speaker: THE CRYPT
dialogues.text: The men come in with the box and set it up on two stone supports. They group themselves around it and stand a mom with bowed heads.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Rest in peace.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: They all file quietly out. THE CAMERA does not move from position in which it has been set. It remains focused on coffin for a long moment, then, slowly, it begins to DOLL IN. When it has come very close to the coffin the sound o groaning can be heard from within the box, then a muffled cry, movement and the sound of fingernails scraping again the boards.

dialogues.speaker: THE LANDING
dialogues.text: The General sits in his camp chair looking across at the mainland. Above his head the flag is streaming to the nor and a south wind, blowing, ruffles the General's hair and clothing. The General pays no attention to the flag. Oliv half running, comes out of the tunnel.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (excitedly) General! The wind --- look the wind has changed to the South.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The General glances up at the flag indifferently and then turns again to watch the mainland.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's the sirocco -- we'll be able to get away from here -- you can take command of your army

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The General shakes his head.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I have had command for the last time В—-

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Come В—- you'll feel yourself again as soon as we get off this dismal island.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (starting to rise) I shall not leave the island В—В—

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: As he gets to his feet, he staggers. Oliver catches him a looks at him in horrified alarm. Slowly the General nods, answering the unspoken question. He has the plague. Olive takes his arm, passes it over his own shoulder and begins help him toward the tunnel.

dialogues.speaker: TNT. CRYPT
dialogues.text: The coffin is still sealed. But from within comes a muffl crying, the sound of fists beating on the boards, the slithering scrape of nails.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: CLOSE SHOT - Miss Wollsten's face and shoulders. She has managed to free her arms from the heavy blanket. With her arms lifted above her head she is frantically pushing aga the coffin lid. As she struggles she screams and her scre echo and reverberate in the narrow confines of the coffin Exhausted by her futile efforts, Miss Wollsten stops struggling, lies still, breathing deeply, her heavy breat echoing. Then she tries to turn in the coffin. It is too narrow. A she beats on the lid. Then she tries to dig her way out w her nails. The scrape of her nails on the dull and echoin wood is the only sound. Finally, even this is too much fo her fading strength. She lies quiet, softly moaning.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oliver and the General come up the stairs. With Oliver supporting the sick man, they start down the corridor jus Cathy comes out from her room. She watches the two men go down the corridor. She follows them. When they turn into General's room, she stands waiting in the corridor. A mom later, Oliver comes out.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (as he passes Cathy) I'm going to get Albrecht. Watch the General for me.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Cathy nods and goes on into the General's room.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Fully clothed, the General lies on his bed. Cathy comes i and stands beside him. The General looks up at her.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The wind has changed. There's no more danger for the army. You can go.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Cathy looks toward the window.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (looking toward the window) It's getting dark. I can't leave now.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (weakly) In the morning -- go. I'll not die until then В—- I'll not die В—В— I'll watch -В— they shall not hurt you.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (comfortingly) ShhВ—В—В— it's all right -В— I'll be all right.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: They shall not hurt you

dialogues.speaker: THE LEDGE OUTSIDE THE CRYPT
dialogues.text: MED. LONG SHOT~В— the mouth of the crypt is solid black i night. From it comes a low mutter of sound.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The coffin is silhouetted against the lighter darkness of night outside the crypt. Here the muttering, moaning and whining of the entombed woman sounds louder.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Miss Wollsten is almost exhausted by her struggles. Her single garment is torn from her exertions; her face is scratched and bleeding. She lifts her hands again to tear the wooden ceiling of her prison. INSERT        MISS WOLLSTEN'S HANDS. The nails are ragged broken; blood streams from under them. CLOSE SHOT В— Miss Wollsten. She ceases to struggle; lies quietly, her eyes open. There is an expression of awarene in her face, almost as if she were listening to something Very faintly, but growing in volume, reverberated by the narrow confines can be heard a rhythmic tapping. The soun gets louder and louder. CLOSE SHOT of the crypt wall. Water is dripping down onto coffin. It drops with a certain, finite measure like the "vrykolaka", quickly and rhythmically. Several times Miss Wollsten's lips move as if repeating t words. Then another word begins to come in from underneat the phrases of the General. At first it is so low in volu then it is barely perceptible,then it grows in volume.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Vrykolaka -- Vrykolaka --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: SHOT of the crypt wall. The water continues to drip onto coffin in the same rhythm as the word~

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: CLOSE SHOT В— Miss Wollsten's face. She is listening to t drumming of the water on the coffin. The word "Vrykolaka" repeated over and over again to the same rhythm grows lou and more insistent. She breathes rapidly. She turns her h from side to side, then finally her whole body tenses, he mouth opens and she screams.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (screaming) Vrykolaka!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: With the word a convulsive movement, a frenzy of strength takes possession of her. She arches her back -and forces whole body against the lid of the coffin. It begins to splinter.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Albrecht is seated at his work bench. He has a small squa of emery paper in his hand and is meticulously attempting remove the dirt and corrosion of the ages from Poseidon's bronze trident. Oliver is watching him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It doesn't look much like the fish spears I knew back in Marblehead..

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (holding it up between him and the light) Our friend, Poseidon, didn't use it for fishing. He raked the sea with it and stirred up the big waves.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (getting up) I'll go up and take a look at the General В—- perhaps sit with him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He won't even know you're there. He is delirious.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: All the more reason to watch him. He's had some wild notions lately.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Don't bother. Go to bed and get some sleep. I'll be working late. (pointing upstairs) I can hear any movement down here.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (hesitating) Well В—В—

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Go ahead. I'll wake you up when I go to bed. Then you can watch him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Thank you, I'll do that. Good night.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oliver walks to the stairs.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Miss Wollsten is emerging from the shattered coffin. Ther a wild and maniacal gleam in her eyes. The remnants of th white blanket still cling about her shoulders. Her white nightgown is in voluminous tatters about her bony body. S starts out from the crypt.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: An oil lamp is burning on the dresser and a lighted lychn stands on a little table beside Cathy's bed. Cathy is in propped up against the pillows. Her face is drawn, her ey unhappy and almost haunted. Thea sits on the foot of Cath bed, watching her anxiously.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You should sleep, Cathy. Lie down and close your eyes. Try to forget everything.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (shaking her head) When I close my eyes, I see Miss Wollsten. I can't think of anything else.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (gently) She is dead В— at peace.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: With a movement so sudden that it startles Thea, Cathy si upright.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (feverishly) Suppose, she isn't dead. Suppose it was a cataleptic attack?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It was, the plague

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (interrupting) We quarreled. She never dared get angry or frightened -- but I said things to her -- it was an attack, I know it was.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Half convinced by Cathy's certainty, Thea gets up from th bed.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Then let us go to her, Cathy. We'll make sure В— and your mind will be at rest.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Cathy shrinks back against the pillows, her eyes        w terror.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (whispering) Oh, no В—- I couldn't Thea. I couldn't go into the crypt.  I'm afraid, you know I'm afraid.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: For a moment, Thea stands looking at Cathy in silence. Th with an air of decision she crosses to the dresser. She p up a shawl, then puts out the oil lamp. The room fills wi shadows and only the dim glow of the lychnos illuminates scene.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (half fearfully half hopefully) What are you going to do?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Thea goes to the door and there turns back to face Cathy.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'll be back soon. Don't worry anymore, Cathy.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Thea goes out, quietly closing the door behind her. Cathy stares after her.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A candle burns beside the bed. In the bed the Genera~ lie restlessly tossing, muttering in delirium.

dialogues.speaker: INT. THE GIRLS' ROOM NIGHT
dialogues.text: The lychnos is burning dimly on a little table beside Cat bed. She lies awake, her eyes wide open, watching the sha across the ceiling. She hears Oliver's footsteps, listens identifies them, then resumes looking at the shadows.

dialogues.speaker: THE CRYPTS
dialogues.text: Thea descends the steps to the two paths and starts to ta the right-hand turn. She stops as she sees something ahea her and peers out into the darkness. There is a low moani sound. It stops. She takes two steps forward. The moaning sounds again. Thea is frightened. She stops a moment and decides to take the left-hand path to the cypress grove a the beach. She has hardly disappeared from view into the darkness of the left-hand path, when Miss Wollsten comes along the path from the crypts. She wanders in a dazed condition and there is madness in her eyes. She seems puz as to which way she should go.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Thea walks through the cypress grove under the dark trees She is nervous and stops several times. Even the sudden t of a nightingale causes her to catch her breath in surpri and stand stock still until she has identified the sound, smile at her own nervousness and pass on. All the little night sounds of the wood are exaggerated and nerve shatte to her oversensitive ears. Finally, she reaches the littl beach at the end of the cliffs and stands here safe; the space around her a guarantee against surprise.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Albrecht is nodding over his work bench. He almost falls asleep, but catches himself and takes a draught of beer f the glass beside him. He then goes on polishing the tride

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Thea, listening and alert, starts to climb the steps. A sudden break of surf on the shingle of the beach makes he tense. She goes on up the steps to the landing.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Thea comes up. The dark tunnel faces her. In the center through the broken roofing a shaft of moonlight cuts in. stands hesitantly before the opening, then almost as if taking her courage into her hands, she begins to walk slo shuffling one foot after the other.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Thea comes through the darkness. MED. FULL SHOT - the patch of moonlight in the tunnel. Th comes into the patch of moonlight and breathes a little m easily. She starts to take a firmer step. Ahead of her in darkness is a tiny unidentified noise. She freezes. CLOSE SHOT - Thea. She listens. Again there is the tiny unidentifiable noise; someone moving.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (softly) Who is there?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She waits for an answer. The echo of her voice is flung b at her, "Who is there В—В— Who is there" and dies away on word 'Who В—В— Who." MED. FULL SHOT - Thea in the tunnel. Ahead of her in the darkness is the movement of something white.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Is that you, Oliver?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The echoes ring around her with her own words. They die a CLOSE SHOT В— Thea. She peers into the darkness.

dialogues.speaker: INT THE TUNNEL AHEAD OF THEA
dialogues.text: A dimly seen figure has advanced a few steps. Thea can se is a woman. MED. CLOSE SHOT - THEA.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Cathy?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: FULL SHOT - Thea and the dim figure ahead of her. From th darkness comes a, ringing peal of maniacal laughter and a shouted name.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Cathy!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Thea turns and runs back toward the landing. Miss Wollste dimly seen figure disappears in the other direction.

dialogues.speaker: THE MOUTH OF THE TUNNEL
dialogues.text: Miss Wollsten comes running madly out of the mouth of the tunnel. She stops, peers around suspiciously, then goes t the door of the house and opens it softly.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The fire is low in the brazier. At his work bench Albrech has tipped his chair back against the wall and is sleepin Before him on the bench lies the bronze trident, its shar burnished points catching the fire light. Miss Wollsten creeps in, closes the door softly behind her and on tipto with the cunning of madness, crosses the room to Albrecht She looks at him. He continues to sleep. Stealthily she reaches between his limp hands and takes up the trident. With the trident in her hand she begins to cross the main room toward the stairs.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He is fitfully tossing.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Thea still very frightened, crouches against the stone wh supports Cerberus. She listens and there is no sound and finally taking courage, she begins to walk through the gr of cypress trees to the house.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Cathy lies still, wide awake, her eyes on the shadows on ceiling. Suddenly the door opens-- quietly and closes aga Cathy half turns her head.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Thea?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: There is a rush in the darkness a stifled exclamation of fear, a quick blow with the trident and Cathy falls back her pillow dead, blood streaming from two puncture marks her throat. Miss Wollsten straightens, gazes about her fo moment, then disappears into the shadows of the room.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Thea comes in, closes the door softly behind her, smiles she sees Albrecht asleep, crosses to him and shakes him awake.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh -В— sleeping -- Oliver wouldn't like that. (he listens) Well, everything seems to be all right.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Goodnight.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She starts across the room and up the stairs. Albrecht, realizing his hands are empty, begins looking for the trident.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It is so still that Miss Wollsten's movements around the in the darkness can be heard. Thea opens the door and com in. She looks over at Cathy's bed. Cathy seems to be asle Without bothering to turn up the oil light, Thea turns ba the covers of her bed and begins to undress. Several time she pauses to listen as if she had hoard a slight sound, continues to take off another piece of clothing until she down to her shift. As she begins to pull down the shoulde straps of her shift a little louder noise in the darkness causes her to stop. There is no repetition of the sound. Again she starts to slip down her shoulder straps.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Albrecht is still looking for his trident. He finally giv up and takes a drink of beer.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The General is tossing wildly. He is awake and his eyes a glazed with fever. He gets up. He is dressed in his unifo trousers and a shirt. He wears neither boots nor tunic. H begins to stagger toward the door.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The General comes out of his room, supporting himself with one hand against the wall.  He moves blindly into th corridor. Several times he passes his hand before his eye if trying to clear his vision, but the blindness of the plague is upon him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: CLOSER SHOT - He comes up the stairs. He finds the door t the girls' room by touch and opens it. He has to support himself on the door jamb to prevent collapse. He shuffles

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The General blindly gropes his way in. CLOSE SHOT В— Thea. She looks over in horror from the bed where she is now lying. MED. FULL SHOT - The General as he gropes his way across Cathy's bed. He kneels down beside it. CLOSE SHOT В— The General and Cathy. He gropes over her f with his hand. One hand touches the wound at her throat. touches the blood stained hand against the fingers of the other hand to test the wetness, then gropes again for the wound. CLOSE SHOT В— The General and Cathy. He touches the two puncture marks.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (muttering) Vrykolaka.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: His hand goes down to feel Cathy's heart beat. There is n The General straightens up and from his belt takes the sm sharp stick of hazel-wood. He turns and begins blindly staggering toward the other bed with outstretched hands. unseeing footsteps take him out of the periphery of the l into the darkness. CLOSE SHOT - Thea. She lies still, holding her breath, tr desperately not to move, not to make a sound, not to attr the General's attention and, give direction to his murder footsteps. She looks up at the shadows on the ceiling. Th lychnos casts weird moving shadows. CLOSE SHOT -- The General, as he gropes his way.  CLOSE SHOT - Thea, straining to see into the shadows beyo her bed. Suddenly, her face becomes completely terrorized Out of the darkness beyond the bed materialises the gener hand holding the hazel-wood stick, as it comes into the periphery of the light from to lychnos. CLOSEUP - Thea's face. She can no longer control herself. screams. MED. FULL SHOT - The General comes out of the darkness, throws himself blindly, toward Thea. ANOTHER ANGLE - silently, swiftly, Miss Wollsten comes ou the darkness, the trident gleaming in her hand. She strik down. The General's hands fall limp and harmless. The haz stick falls to the floor as the General collapses over th bed.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oliver, rubbing the sleep from his eyes, startled by Thea scream, comes out into the corridor. Suddenly he becomes completely alert as from the girls' r Miss Wollsten emerges. Oliver looks at her with shocked horror and then rushes towards the girls' room.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Miss Wollsten comes rushing down the stairs. Albrecht loo at her in amazement. His glass of beer falls to the floor She dashes through the door into the darkness.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Albrecht comes out and peers off into the moonlight. Evidently he sees the direction of Miss Wollsten's flight Picking up a lantern, he runs after her.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: MED. CLOSE SHOT - The General lies on Thea's bed. Thea, n in her robe, and Oliver bent over him. The General opens eyes. He seems darned, but his lace is calm in contrast t his former appearance  He turns his head slightly in Thea direction.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (in a whisper) Theodosia --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (with great sympathy) Not Theodosia. Theodosia's daughter -- your daughter.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The General looks from one to the other uncomprehendingly

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Daughter -- my daughter --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She was born before your wife returned here to die. You never knew.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: An expression of full realization comes into the General' face. He attempts to smile at Thea and makes an effort to move his hand toward her. Thea understands the gesture an puts her hand over his warmly. 'The touch of her hand ind a state of euphoria in the General. He looks at Thea gratefully, peacefully.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Fog is rising from the sea so that although the temple is still clear, the cliff ends abruptly in a curtain of grey watery vapor. Miss Wollsten, the trident held before her, comes running into the temple. She pauses, looks forward the grey wall before her. Behind her she can hear Albrech footsteps. She throws down the trident, it rings on the marble pavement of the temple. Then, almost with composur she walks slowly forward and suddenly disappears into the grey fog. From the fog comes a long, descending scream. A moment later, Albrecht appears with the lantern and stand looking off. Glancing down, Albrecht sees the trident gleaming in the light. He picks it up, examines it --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (softly to himself) With Poseidon's trident she paid her way to Hades. He let her pass through the portals into his dark realm.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The wind blows free from the South.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It is early morning and the cliffs cast long shadows over rippling catspaws on the water. A small boat is drawn up the beach. Albrecht's man servant stands in the stern, leaning on a sculling oar that he presses against the bot to hold the boat steady. Thea, with her bundle of possess beside her, sits on the thwart. Oliver stands on the beac holding the bow, and talking to Albrecht.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (pressing Albrecht's hand) Goodbye.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: May life be good to you both. As for the others В—В— they will be quiet here В—В— and I will be with them.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Albrecht smiles at Thea and Oliver. Oliver steps into the bow.. The servant shoves the boat off from the beach.
